author: Jenn Gidman
title: Longing for That Elusive Snow? It May Be Coming
text: US / snowstorm Longing for That Elusive Snow? It May Be Coming Winter storm set to descend on Northeast, mid-Atlantic states this weekend By Jenn Gidman, Newser Staff Posted Jan 3, 2024 9:13 AM CST Copied Stock photo. (Getty Images/COM and O) Bing Crosby might get his snow after all, though not in time for Christmas 2023. A winter storm is set to descend this weekend upon the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states, though the Weather Channel concedes it's not yet clear how powerful the storm will be or what its track will be. What is clear is that residents in those regions will likely be getting some snow, rain, wind, or a mix, with the possibility that the weather system could even morph into a nor'easter. CNN notes that the storm system from the west will bring cool rain to most of the South, but that "confidence in the storm's exact track drops after it leaves the Southeast." "Heavy precipitation will spread across the Southeast/mid-Atlantic and possibly the Northeast this coming weekend, with increasing potential for heavy snow to the north and west of the low," according to the Weather Prediction Center. It adds, cryptically: "Exact amounts and precipitation type for some of the major East Coast cities remains highly uncertain at this point, but does need to be watched." Wherever the snow ends up falling, it could potentially end a snow drought that's endured for going on two years. New York City, for example, hasn't seen more than an inch of snow for almost 700 days; last year, a grand total of 2.3 inches fell in Central Park—the city's "least snowy" calendar year ever, per CNN. Philly and DC saw similarly low snowfall. However the nearing precipitation ends up coming down in the targeted areas, the Washington Post notes that it's set to hit between 10am on Saturday and 8am on Sunday. (Read more snowstorm stories.) Report an error

author: latercera.com
title: La historia del Cártel de Los Zetas y un novato del FBI - La Tercera
text:
Gonzalo Valdivia Hace 4 horas Tiempo de lectura: 4 minutos El Cártel de Los Zetas versus un novato: la siniestra historia que mezcló carreras de caballos y lavado de dinero Cowboy Cartel es el nombre de la serie documental de Apple TV+ que presenta las experiencias de Scott Lawson, un agente del FBI que destapó el mayor caso de lavado de dinero en la historia de Texas. “Lo que nos interesaba era tomar un tema que en muchos sentidos está muy saturado y entrar desde una perspectiva diferente”, señalan sus directores a Culto.
compartir Comentarios Scott Lawson siempre soñó con convertirse en policía . Su padre fue policía de la comisaría de un pueblo pequeño y lo llevaba a patrullar desde pequeño, para desagrado de su madre. Su destino, escrito desde temprana edad, se confirmó cuando salió del colegio: postuló al FBI, fue aceptado y egresó en 2009.
Pese a que no tenía la intención de trabajar en el sur de Estados Unidos, fue asignado a San Antonio, Texas. Como hablaba algo de español, sus supervisores lo terminaron enviando a Laredo, uno de los puntos más complejos de la frontera con México, en gran parte porque allí se encuentra el mayor cruce comercial entre ambos países.
Lawson siempre quiso detener a los malos, pero lo que le esperaba excedió cualquier expectativa. Siendo apenas un novato, le informaron que el trabajo estaría enfocado en el Cártel de Los Zetas , un grupo criminal del que apenas había escuchado. Se enteró de su pasado como militares y de sus brutales métodos para expandir su influencia en territorio mexicano.
Mientras profundizaba sus conocimientos en torno al grupo criminal que en ese momento lideraba Miguel Treviño (respaldado por uno de sus hermanos, Omar Treviño), una pista lo llevó a descubrir la conexión entre las carreras de caballos en Estados Unidos y el dinero de Los Zetas. Se internó en una historia que múltiples profesionales describen como única, por la combinación de sus ingredientes y por constituirse como el mayor caso de lavado de dinero que se recuerde en Texas.
De El Oso a True Detective: dónde ver las series nominadas a los Emmy 2024 Natalie Portman: “El sentimiento más liberador que existe es cuando interpreto a un personaje y dejo de pensar” Cowboy cartel , la serie documental que presenta esa historia en cuatro capítulos (todos en Apple TV+ ), tiene a Scott Lawson como su principal entrevistado. Vestido con una camisa cuadrilles azul, recuerda sus experiencias asistiendo a carreras y tratando de encontrar pruebas contundentes que le permitieran construir confirmar sus sospechas.
“Esta historia sólo podíamos contarla si ellos querían contarla”, señala a Culto Dan Johnstone, director de la producción junto a Castor Fernandez. Lawson sigue perteneciendo al FBI, pero sólo puso un requisito: “Su única condición fue que no se tratara solo de una historia sobre él”.
La historia continua más abajo
Más sobre Series La Diplomática sella su regreso: cuándo llegarán sus nuevos capítulos a Netflix Hace 11 horas Mira el trailer de la ambiciosa serie que junta a Cate Blanchett y Alfonso Cuarón 7 ago 2024 En efecto, Cowboy cartel incluye a otras voces del FBI , como Raul Permodo y un tal Jason Hodge, quien “debido a las preocupaciones de seguridad relacionadas con esta investigación (...) no puede ser visto en cámara”, se explica al espectador. Él aporta con su versión sentado en una sala apenas iluminada.
“Creo que la magia está en tener a los participantes, a las personas que estuvieron allí y puedan decir cosas como: ‘recuerdo dónde estaba cuando’. Y simplemente ponerlos frente a la cámara y dejar que compartan las historias”, plantea Castor Fernandez.
Aunque en el centro del caso estaba uno de los carteles más feroces, la dupla de realizadores no estaba interesada en explorar la violencia. “Eso no era lo que nos interesaba. Lo que nos interesaba era tomar un tema que en muchos sentidos está muy saturado, en términos de cárteles, narcos, tráfico de drogas, y entrar desde una perspectiva diferente ”, indica Fernandez. Y agrega: “Caballos, lavado de dinero y cárteles... Creo que el hecho de que esas tres cosas estén en la misma oración es lo más sorprendente”.
Uno de los aspectos que enfatiza la serie documental es que, de no haberse producido la investigación en el momento en que se originó, difícilmente habrían podido llegar al fondo del asunto y los responsables habrían podido seguir actuando en total impunidad. “No sabíamos lo inteligentes que eran ni lo sofisticada que era la operación”, reconoce Fernandez, quien destaca que lo más complejo fue “describir y mostrarle al público lo que es el lavado de dinero y hablar sobre los delitos financieros de una manera que fuera emocionante y entretenida, y a veces divertida y aterradora”.
“Esperamos mostrarles que el daño que estos cárteles hacen, las organizaciones que ellos dirigen, es mucho más perverso. Afecta todos los aspectos de nuestra vida. No es una historia de nosotros y ellos. Es una historia de nosotros. Esta es una historia que afecta a las instituciones globales, que nos afecta globalmente”, reflexiona Johnstone.
“Esta es una historia de crimen, cárteles y drogas, pero también es una historia sobre personas. Personas muy reales, que tienen miedos y emociones muy reales, que cometieron errores, que tuvieron victorias y derrotas. Y creo que eso realmente se refleja en la serie”, finaliza Fernandez.
Sigue leyendo en Culto Fran Healy de Travis: “Yo crecí pobre, sé el valor de una entrada y no quiero sentir que no le he dado valor a un show” Yo fui Machuca: a 20 años de la película que remeció a Chile Willy Semler: “Tengo toda la fe de que voy a volver a una vida normal en muy poco tiempo” Mon Laferte: “Recién a mis 40 años dejé de tener miedo de hablar del abuso que sufrí” Los reality shows más controversiales de la historia: sexo, mentiras y video Deborah Eisenberg: “Me parece extraño que muchos lectores se sientan traicionados por la conducta de Alice Munro” Comenta Los comentarios en esta sección son exclusivos para suscriptores. Suscríbete aquí.

Sandar Estrella Oporto Hace 13 horas Imperdibles La predicción que hizo Steve Jobs en 1983 y que vivimos en estos días La Tercera La sacrificada historia detrás de SofiaTrends, el emprendimiento de zapatos que la rompe en redes sociales La Cuarta Código swinger: mitos y reglas de una práctica que aún es tabú La Cuarta Soy cardiólogo y este es el snack que siempre elijo para adelgazar y proteger mi corazón La Tercera Un hito: Los Bunkers realizarán su propio MTV Unplugged Felipe Retamal The Smashing Pumpkins y Franz Ferdinand lideran el cartel de Fauna Primavera 2024 Equipo de Culto Tool se acerca a Chile: la esperada banda podría debutar en el país en 2025 Claudio Vergara Lo que dejó el cuestionado final de House of the Dragon 2 (y por qué no volverá antes de 2026) Exclusivo suscriptor Gonzalo Valdivia

author: Rick Sobey
title: Two Southie churches broken into, K-9 Duke helps bust suspect in basement: Boston Police
text:
A couple of Southie churches were broken into within a few hours overnight, according to police who arrested three suspects with the help of K-9 Duke.
The break-ins Wednesday night and early Thursday were reported at the old St. Vincent Catholic Church on E Street, and St. Monica Catholic Church on Old Colony Avenue.
Police officers first responded at around 11:50 p.m. for a breaking and entering call at St. Vincent’s after two suspects were reportedly seen heading into the church with two bags.
As responding officers were about to enter the church, the two suspects exited the building and were detained, police said.
“Upon further investigation it was revealed that both suspects had broken into the church to steal copper wire,” police said in a statement. “The officers located the suspects bags they had entered the church with and it contained hand tools and numerous pieces of copper wire obtained from the building.”
Southie men Michael Donovan, 37, and Brendan Delaney, 50, were arrested and charged with: possession of burglarious instruments and breaking and entering in the nighttime. Both suspects were expected to be arraigned at South Boston District Court.
Related Articles Crime & Public Safety | Top 10 crime stories of 2023, from murder to Turtleboy Crime & Public Safety | Sheep on the lam captured by Boston police officers, returned to Southie Christmas service Crime & Public Safety | Santa delivers presents to South Boston kids by water taxi (Photos) Crime & Public Safety | 2 deaf people robbed outside South Boston Burger King Then about four hours later at 3:44 a.m., police officers responded to another church break-in at St. Monica’s, which is about a mile away from St. Vincent’s.
Responding officers to the church saw a broken window that was large enough for a person to fit through. The officers then requested a K-9 officer and took a perimeter around the building.
When K-9 Duke entered the church, the dog alerted officers to the basement — where Duke and the officers found the suspect.
The 61-year-old Southie man was detained, and originally gave a false name to officers, police said. His true name, Steven Cyr, was learned during the booking process.
Cyr was placed under arrest and charged with: breaking and entering in the nighttime and furnishing a false name. A police spokesperson did not immediately say what Cyr was allegedly trying to steal at St. Monica’s.
Cyr was expected to be arraigned at South Boston District Court.

author: Sponsored
title: Unlocking the Nutritional Bonanza: Feeding Dubia Roaches to Reptiles | The Emory Wheel
text: Reptile enthusiasts constantly seek the best ways to provide their scaly friends with a balanced and nutritious diet. While the market is flooded with various options, one food source that has gained popularity among reptile keepers is Dubia roaches. These small insects offer many nutritional benefits for reptiles, making them an excellent choice for a well-rounded diet. This article explores the nutritional advantages of feeding Dubia roaches to reptiles, shedding light on why they have become a staple for many reptile owners. Additionally, you can visit websites like [https://www.topflightdubia.com/](https://www.topflightdubia.com/) to learn more about sourcing high-quality Dubia roaches for your reptiles, ensuring they receive the best nutrition possible. High Protein Content: One of the primary reasons why Dubia roaches are a top choice for reptile diets is their exceptionally high protein content. Protein is essential for reptiles as it helps in muscle development, growth, and overall health. These roaches provide a whopping 35-50% protein by dry weight, making them an excellent source of protein for reptiles. Balanced Calcium to Phosphorus Ratio: Maintaining the correct calcium-to-phosphorus ratio is crucial for reptiles’ skeletal health. Dubia roaches naturally have a balanced Ca: P ratio, typically around 1:1, which aligns perfectly with the dietary requirements of most reptile species. This helps prevent metabolic bone diseases and ensures healthy bone development in pets. High Fiber Content: In addition to protein, Dubia roaches are also rich in dietary fiber. This fiber aids in digestion and helps reptiles maintain a healthy digestive system. It can be particularly beneficial for species that require more fiber in their diets, such as herbivorous reptiles. Low in Fat: While some fat is essential for reptiles, excessive intake can lead to obesity and other health issues. Dubia roaches are relatively low in fat, making them an ideal option for reptiles that need to maintain a lean body condition. This is especially important for species like bearded dragons and leopard geckos. Abundance of Essential Vitamins and Minerals: Dubia roaches are not just a protein powerhouse but also packed with essential vitamins and minerals. They are a good source of vitamin B12, which is crucial for nerve function and overall health. Additionally, they contain vitamins A and D and minerals like iron and zinc, contributing to a well-rounded nutritional profile. Gut-Loading Potential: One unique advantage of Dubia roaches is their capacity for gut-loading. Gut-loading involves feeding the roaches nutritious foods before offering them to your reptiles. This process allows you to enhance the roaches’ nutritional content, giving your pets even more benefits. Common gut-loading foods include vegetables, fruits, and high-calcium supplements. Easy to Digest: Dubia roaches have a soft exoskeleton, making them easy for reptiles to digest. Unlike other feeder insects with harder shells, Dubia roaches are less likely to cause impaction or digestive issues in your reptiles. Reduced Risk of Allergies: Insects like crickets and mealworms can sometimes trigger [allergies ](https://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/animal-allergy)in reptile keepers due to the presence of allergenic proteins. Dubia roaches, on the other hand, are less likely to cause allergies, making them a safer option for those with sensitivities. Summing it Up: In conclusion, feeding Dubia roaches to reptiles offers many nutritional benefits. Their high protein content, balanced calcium-to-phosphorus ratio, and abundant essential vitamins and minerals make them an ideal choice for reptile owners. Their low-fat content, easy digestibility, and gut-loading potential further solidify their position as a top-notch feeder insect. As with any aspect of reptile care, it’s important to research and understand the specific dietary requirements of your reptile species. While Dubia roaches can be an excellent addition to their diet, it’s crucial to provide a varied diet that includes other feeder insects, vegetables, and supplements as needed. Ultimately, Dubia roaches have earned their place as a nutritional powerhouse in reptile husbandry, helping reptile enthusiasts keep their scaly companions healthy and thriving. So, to provide your reptile with a balanced and nutritious diet, consider incorporating Dubia roaches into their feeding regimen and watch them flourish in good health.

author: María Alejandra Trujillo
title: Fort Valley State University Embarks on Transformative Renovation Project
text:
In the heart of Georgia, Fort Valley State University (FVSU) is on the brink of a transformative journey. Starting February 15th, 2024, FVSU will revitalize three of its cornerstone buildings - Founders Hall, Lyons, and Bywaters. Erected in the heart of the 20th century, these buildings are about to leap into the future. This ambitious project is not just about bricks and mortar; it's about shaping a modern campus life, enriching student services, and ensuring the university remains a beacon of learning and opportunity. With a ceremony that took place just yesterday, the university community buzzes with anticipation for what's to come.
Blueprint for the Future
The renovation plan for FVSU's three historic buildings is a bold step towards integrating modern amenities with the university's rich heritage. Vice President for Student Affairs and Enrollment Management, Timothy Hatchett, voiced his excitement at the ceremony, stating, "This renovation will greatly benefit our students, providing them with the resources and environment they need to succeed." From the Bywaters building focusing on nursing to the Founders building being tailored for classroom learning, each structure is set to cater to the evolving needs of the FVSU family. The standout feature of this renovation is the Lyons Building which is envisioned to become the university's heart, offering a centralized location for academic advising, career services, civic engagement, and much more. This strategic consolidation aims to streamline student support, fostering a vibrant campus community.
Legacy Meets Innovation
The selected buildings for renovation, standing since between 1929 and 1966, are testaments to FVSU's storied past. This renovation project is a delicate balancing act of preserving the historical essence while infusing the campus with contemporary spirit. It's a nod to the university's legacy, with an eye firmly on the future. The initiative is expected to span 18 months, a period during which the university will witness a metamorphosis of its physical and academic landscape. This transformation is not just about the aesthetic appeal but about enhancing the functionality and accessibility of student services, ensuring that FVSU remains a competitive and attractive option for current and prospective students.
Centering Student Success
At the core of the renovation project is a commitment to student success. By creating a centralized hub in the Lyons Building, FVSU acknowledges the importance of having academic and support services within easy reach. This approach not only enhances the efficiency of service delivery but also encourages students to engage more deeply with the resources available to them. The dedication to specialized spaces, like the nursing-focused Bywaters building, underscores FVSU's dedication to providing tailored educational pathways. This renovation is a clear signal that FVSU is investing in its students' futures, creating environments that inspire learning, discovery, and personal growth.
As Fort Valley State University embarks on this significant renovation project, the excitement within the university community is palpable. These buildings, rich in history and memories, are set to be transformed into vibrant centers of learning and student engagement. FVSU's commitment to blending tradition with innovation is a powerful testament to its dedication to academic excellence and student success. With the project's completion set for 2025, the future looks bright for FVSU, as it prepares to open new doors of opportunity and continue its legacy of empowerment and education.

author: https://www.dailystar.co.uk/authors/adam-cailler/
title: 10-day Indian summer scorcher to blast Britain as maps go deep crimson
text:
Brits are set to bask in a 10-day blast of hot sunshine, with the mercury rising as high as 21C in some parts of England, just days after a wet start to the month Something went wrong, please try again later.
Invalid email Something went wrong, please try again later.

Something went wrong, please try again later.
Never miss any of the fun stuff. Get the biggest stories and wackiest takes from the Daily Star, including our special WTF Wednesday email
Millions of Brits are poised to enjoy a 10-day heatwave in the coming days, following a rain-drenched start to the month, according to recent weather maps.
Netweather's forecast data indicates temperatures could reach up to 21 degrees in England on October 17, with no area south of the Scottish border expected to see maximum temperatures below 14C. London and its surrounding regions are predicted to experience the highest temperatures of around 20-21C, while Birmingham, Liverpool and Manchester can expect temperatures between 16 and 18C, as per the latest charts.
Scotland is likely to be slightly chillier overall on that day, with temperatures only reaching as high as 11C in some parts, although Edinburgh is set to hit around 15C at its peak and a warm 17C is forecast along the English border.
READ MORE: UK high street closure crisis claid bare in images of abandoned TGI Fridays
Click for more of the latest news from across the world from the Daily Star.
In contrast, Wales is anticipated to see temperatures ranging between 15 and 17C, with Northern Ireland predicted to have temperatures of 13-14C, reports the Express.
